TypeSignature.Value: public class Command : System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl, System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler, System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler
.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit Command extends System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl implements class System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler, class System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Creates a user interface element that enables users to invoke ASP.NET event handlers and it provides a means to post user input from UI elements back to the server. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control displays as an interactive UI element on the requesting device. The label of the UI element comes from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property, which is inherited from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl> base class.
> [!CAUTION] > Avoid using special characters in ASP.NET mobile Web page URLs. The HREF tags generated for posting `Command` events back to the server are not strictly validated. For example, a URL that includes spaces results in the generation of WML that cannot be handled by some WML browsers.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to attach command events. Clicking either of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> buttons raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event. The user-defined function uses the `CommandEventArgs` argument to see which <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> button was clicked.
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

Gets or sets whether the specified control causes server-side validation to occur on all controls on the form. The default value is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.value: if the specified control causes server-side validation to occur on all controls on the form; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks For validation to occur on a form, the form must be submitted with a control that raises validation, and must have its <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CausesValidation%2A> property set to `true`. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control is currently the only control that raises validation.

Docs.summary: Occurs when a user activates a control. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control is activated, it raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event. For more information, see the "Device-Specific Rendering" and "Device-Specific Behavior" sections in <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command?displayProperty=fullName>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to attach command events. Clicking either of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> buttons raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event. The user-defined function uses the `CommandEventArgs` argument to see which <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> button was clicked.
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information on the Web Forms code model, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

Docs.value: The name of the that raised the event.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the render style for the . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.value: A value indicating the render style for the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Access the two available types through the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat> enumeration.
<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat?displayProperty=fullName> (default) The command is rendered as a button.
<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat?displayProperty=fullName> The command is rendered as a link.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Format%2A> property supports the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat?displayProperty=fullName> value only on devices that support JavaScript as indicated by the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.HttpCapabilitiesBase.JavaScript%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to the use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Format%2A> property to render the command as a link or a button.
> [!NOTE] > The following code example uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code example must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).
<!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-csharp[MobileItemCommandSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileItemCommandSample/cs/default.aspx#1)] --> <!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-vb[MobileItemCommandSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileItemCommandSample/vb/default.aspx#1)] -->

Docs.summary: Sets or returns the URL of the image source for the control when the control is rendered as an image button. The default value is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.value: The URL of the image source for the when the control is rendered as an image button.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If this property is not <xref:System.String.Empty> and the device can handle image buttons, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control uses the image instead of a button or link text.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance bool IsFormSubmitControl() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the control submits the form. The default is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.returns: if the control submits the form; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Mobile controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command>, can override this method to determine whether this is a control used for form submission. Other controls can be extended by providing logic to programmatically determine whether or not they must be submit controls, for example, by checking for specific properties.
> [!NOTE] > A control is considered to be a form-submit control only if it implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> method to capture the postback event. Otherwise, it is not registered for the default event handler, even if the method returns `true`.

Docs.summary: Occurs when the user selects a command that is associated with an item. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event handler is defined, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control notifies the handler when an item event is generated through user interaction.
Unlike the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event is bubbled up to the parent controls. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event rendering is device-specific and is discussed in detail in the "Device-Specific Behavior" section of <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command?displayProperty=fullName>.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event is raised after an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event. In a scenario where you repeat the same set of actions each time a command button is clicked, you can use either the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandName%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandArgument%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control to identify which command button the user clicked.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event for multiple commands on a page.
<!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-csharp[MobileItemCommandSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileItemCommandSample/cs/default.aspx#1)] --> <!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-vb[MobileItemCommandSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileItemCommandSample/vb/default.aspx#1)] -->

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the adapter associated with the control has handled loading the post data. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.returns: if the adapter associated with this control has handled loading the post data; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is called by the <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler.LoadPostData%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
> [!NOTE] > Different devices might provide their data back to the calling server in different ways.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnClick(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: An object defined by an that contains event data.
Docs.summary: Called when the user activates the control. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> method raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event. Inheriting classes can override the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> method to perform other tasks.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnItemCommand(class System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: An object that contains event data.
Docs.summary: Called when the user activates the control. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event. Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event is raised after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event. This is useful when you must take the same actions for multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> buttons. You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandName%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandArgument%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control to identify which <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> button was clicked.

Docs.summary: Raises the event. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

Docs.summary: Raises events for the control when it posts back to the server. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.RaisePostBackEvent%2A> method is used internally by the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control when it is clicked to raise a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void RaisePostDataChangedEvent() cil managed

Docs.summary: Notifies the ASP.NET application that the state of the control has changed. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.RaisePostDataChangedEvent%2A> method can be overridden in a derived class to raise change events for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control when it posts back to the server. This method is used primarily by control developers.

Docs.summary: Sets or returns the label used when a softkey is displayed. The default value is an empty string (""). This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Docs.value: The label used when a soft key is displayed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property is used only for devices that support softkeys.
If this property is empty, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property of the control is used. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property is empty or its length is less than 9, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property is used for the softkey label. Otherwise, the word `Go` (if it is a submit control command) is displayed.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.SoftkeyLabel%2A> property is truncated to 12 characters (the standard maximum length of a softkey).
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.SoftkeyLabel%2A> property.
